School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300131 China 1 PRESENT ADDRESSES: School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300131, China A core-shell structured catalyst 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 was created to facilitate the reductive amination of pyruvic acid into alanine and the yield of alanine is up to 99 %. The SiO2 shell played a crucial role in spatial isolation effect, preventing the direct hydrogenation of pyruvic acid and improving the selectivity of alanine. By inter-doping Ni and Co, the electronic structure and properties are adjusted, the d-band center is reduced which is beneficial to the desorption of the product and the reaction barrier is reduced. Furthermore, it is proposed that catalysts exhibit better reductive amination reaction performance when there is a smaller difference in adsorption energy between NH3 and H2 atoms on the metal surface. Graphical Abstract Keywords Pyruvic acid Alanine Reductive amination Core-shell structured Ni-Co alloy First-principles Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Alanine, which contains both carboxyl and amino groups within the molecule, is a neutral amino acid that is an important component of human protein structures. It has wide applications in the fields of biology, pharmaceuticals, and food [1–3]. In the food industry, alanine is a natural food additive that provides both sweetness and umami taste. In cosmetics, D-alanine not only has antibacterial properties but also acts as a natural moisturizing ingredient. In the field of biomedicine, alanine is often used as a chiral pharmaceutical intermediate and has important physiological functions, such as participation in glucose metabolism [4,5]. Currently, the production of amino acids is mainly achieved through enzymatic catalysis and fermentation. Sang Yup Lee and colleagues [6] conducted a fermentation process where they overexpressed the genes panD, aspA, and PPC using glucose as the substrate to enhance the production of 3-aminopropionic acid (3-AP) [6]. The inherent instability and susceptibility to inactivation of the pure enzyme pose challenges for enzyme immobilization, thereby impeding the widespread application of l-aspartate-α-decarboxylase (ADC) in industries [7]. This issue can be effectively resolved by implementing whole-cell catalysis approaches. Xin Wang and his team utilized R12 and Q17 mutations in ADC, leading to a significant increase in both yield and productivity of 3-AP within the whole-cell catalytic system [8]. But this kind of method has high production cost and low production efficiency [9]. Furthermore, Amino acids can also be synthesized through chemical methods, including Strecker synthesis [10], Buchere method [11], α-halogenated carboxylic acid amination (Miller synthesis), phase transfer catalysis synthesis, and Gabriel synthesis [12]. Nevertheless, the majority of protocols or catalytic systems encounter drawbacks such as the utilization of organic solvents, extremely toxic cyanide, catalyst deactivation, several steps, and decreased yields. The substrate for catalytic synthesis of amino acids from biomass sources is still in the initial stage. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop a green, clean, and efficient new process for producing amino acids from biomass and its derivatives, which is currently an unresolved challenge. Lactic acid can be easily obtained from substrates derived from biomass and waste glycerol (the main by-product of the biodiesel industry). However, it is difficult, costly, and has low yields to convert lactic acid into alanine [13]. Therefore, we use biologically-derived pyruvic acid to produce alanine, which uses low-cost non-precious metal catalysts. The Zhang’s research group [14] used Ag catalysts to synthesize alanine from pyruvic acid at room temperature in the presence of NO and water, achieving a yield of 90 %. Additionally, they further revealed the reaction pathway from pyruvic acid to alanine. The Yamauchi’s research group [15] synthesized alanine using biologically derived pyruvic acid and NH3·H2O with Ti/TiO2 catalysts through electrochemical methods, achieving a pyruvic acid conversion rate of 89 % and an alanine selectivity of 77 %. The reported catalytic conversion of pyruvic acid into alanine encounters various drawbacks. These include reliance on organic solvents, expensive catalysts, and limited catalyst longevity. Consequently, achieving the reductive amination of pyruvic acid to alanine remains a formidable challenge. The low yield of alanine stems primarily from the direct hydrogenation of pyruvic acid. Additionally, the existence of unsaturated bonds, such as CO, in the chemical structure of pyruvic acid enhances its proneness to polymerization responses in these circumstances, greatly influencing the selectivity of alanine. Evidently, resolving these issues hinges on designing catalysts capable of averting the direct hydrogenation and polymerization of pyruvic acid. Core-shell structure catalysts have garnered significant attention in catalytic reactions due to their unique structural properties. Compared to traditional catalysts, they offer the advantages of having distinct core and shell components, resulting in higher activity and selectivity. Core-shell structure catalysts provide a tunable and complex microenvironment for reactions. By adjusting the structural parameters of the shell and metal core nanoparticles, one can precisely manipulate this microenvironment to effectively regulate interactions between the shell, active metal particles, and reactant molecules. This control allows for the regulation of the diffusion behavior of reactants, intermediates, and products, thereby achieving highly selective products. The microenvironmental effects of core-shell structure catalysts are primarily manifested in metal-support interaction effects, reactant enrichment effects, molecular sieve effects, spatial separation effects, and metal stabilization effects [16]. Herein, we developed a catalyst with core-shell structure (3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2) for the selective conversion of pyruvic acid to alanine through reductive amination. By optimizing the Co to Ni molar ratio, we adjusted electronic properties leading to excellent catalytic performance of the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2. Furthermore, the catalytic performance was improved by adjusting the molar ratio of Si to Co and Ni, which optimized the thickness and pore size of the SiO2 shell. This adjustment helped prevent the direct hydrogenation of pyruvic acid by creating an isolation effect with the SiO2 shell. By combining computational and experimental data, this study also investigates the adsorption and activation mechanisms of reactants, reaction kinetics, geometric structure, and electronic properties to guide the future development of efficient reductive amination catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of core-shell structured catalysts The catalyst precursor was acquired through dispersing metal oxides using ultrasound, then carrying out hydrolysis of TEOS in ammonia to create the catalyst precursor. Next, the precursor underwent calcination and reduction to produce the catalyst. The specific procedures can be found in the Supporting Information provided. The catalysts were labeled xM1-yM2@SiO2-z, with M1 and M2 representing the metal, x and y representing the molar ratio of M1 to M2, and z representing the molar ratio of Si to M1+M2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The processes and instruments for characterizing are available in the Supplementary Material, including X-ray power diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), transmission electron microscope images (TEM), Ammonia Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD), and hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic activity was assessed in a 15 mL stainless steel reactor containing the catalyst, pyruvic acid and aqueous ammonia (25 wt%). To prepare for the experiment, the reactor underwent five rounds of purging with hydrogen gas to remove any remaining air and was pressurized with hydrogen gas to 1 MPa. The reaction occurred at a temperature of 110 ℃ degrees Celsius with the agitation speed set at 1500 revolutions per minute. After the reaction was finished, the catalyst was separated from the liquid product, treated with ortho-phthalaldehyde for derivatization, and then analyzed using liquid chromatography. The specific procedures can be found in the Supporting Information provided. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening of catalysts In order to achieve high yields in the reductive amination of pyruvic acid to alanine, various catalysts were tested. This includes Raney Ni, Ni supported on SiO2, Co supported on SiO2, and Ru supported on carbon. Additionally, catalysts with core-shell structures were prepared, which consisted of transitional single metals (Co@SiO2-0.1 and Ni@SiO2-0.1), as well as transitional double metals (xNi-yCo@SiO2-0.1). These catalysts were then evaluated under the same experimental parameters. And products were analyzed using HPLC-MS, revealing the presence of byproducts such as lactic acid aside from the target product alanine (Figure S6). The Table 1 displays the selectivity of each product among different catalyst. Based on existing literature and organic reaction principles [17–19], the pathways outlined in Scheme 1 propose how the observed products are formed. According to the literature [20–22], alanine is formed through the condensation of a carbonyl compound (pyruvic acid) with NH3 to create an imine, which is subsequently hydrogenated. Meanwhile, pyruvic acid undergoes direct hydrogenation of the CO group, resulting in the production of lactic acid as a byproduct. As illustrated in Table 1, the performance of three catalysts (Raney Ni, Ni/SiO2, and Co/SiO2) exhibited similarities, with lactic acid identified as the main byproduct. In contrast, Ru/C demonstrated heightened hydrogenation capabilities compared to Ni and Co catalysts, producing more production of lactic acid byproducts. These findings suggest that an overabundance of hydrogenation activity within catalysts may impede the reductive amination process of pyruvic acid when direct contact between pyruvic acid and metal occurs. Conversely, Co@SiO2 and Ni@SiO2 catalysts which have a core-shell structure only yield a small amount of lactic acid byproducts, emphasizing the Spatial isolating effect of the SiO2 shell in preventing the attachment of pyruvic acid on the metal active sites. Pyruvic acid initially undergoes an amination reaction on the SiO2 shell to form imine, and then it diffuses through the pores of the SiO2 shell to the metal surface inside the shell, where imine hydrogenation reaction occurs, leading to the formation of alanine. This process prevents pyruvic acid from directly hydrogenating to lactic acid on the metal surface. For the catalysts with Ni to Co molar ratio of 3: 7, Ni and Co could form an alloy, and the addition of Ni could regulate the electronic state and charge density of Co, making the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst exhibit the highest activity for reductive amination as shown in Figs. 7, 8, and 9 from the XRD, XPS, and H2-TPR. For the catalysts with other Ni to Co molar ratio, the interaction between Ni and Co is weak, and the performance of the catalyst is poor. In conclusion, the best results were demonstrated by the catalyst 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.1, with alanine achieving a selectivity of 57 % while maintaining a pyruvic acid conversion rate of 99 %. In the reductive amination of pyruvic acid, the thickness of the shell in core-shell structured catalysts plays a crucial role in determining substrate, intermediate, and product diffusion, influencing that spatial isolation effect of SiO2 shell. To investigate this, by adjusting the molar ratio of Si to Ni-Co, then the SiO2 shell thickness of catalysts was changed, and core-shell structured catalysts were synthesized. The catalysts were then evaluated for their catalytic activity, and the findings are illustrated in Fig. 1. Across all catalysts, pyruvic acid conversion was consistently 99 %. Nevertheless, the selectivity of alanine varied depending on the ratio of Si to Ni-Co. Specifically, the catalyst yielded the highest selectivity for alanine at 64 % with Si to Ni-Co molar ratio of 0.2: 1. Higher molar ratios (0.3: 1, 0.5: 1, and 1: 1) led to decreased alanine selectivity. This trend can be attributed to the sizes of the pores and the surface areas of SiO2 shells (Fig. 10 and Table 3). Higher Si to Ni-Co molar ratios caused smaller pore sizes and longer hole lengths in the SiO2 shell, impeding the diffusion of imine and pyruvic acid, and inhibiting alanine detachment from Ni and Co core, ultimately obtaining lower alanine selectivity. The selectivity of alanine was lower for the catalyst with Si to Ni-Co molar ratio of 0.1: 1, as a large amount of lactic acid is generated. The presence of large pore size and short pore channels in SiO2 shell, attributed to the extremely low Si to Ni-Co ratio. This allowed pyruvic acid to diffuse easily to the Ni-Co core, directing hydrogenation of pyruvic acid to lactic acid occurred. In summary, the best Si to Ni-Co molar ratio in catalyst is 0.2: 1. 3.2 Optimization of reaction conditions To enhance the selectivity of alanine in the reductive amination of pyruvic acid using the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst, the reaction parameters were fine-tuned. Initially, the influence of reaction temperature was examined with other variables held constant ( Fig. 2). The selectivity of alanine rose progressively from 90 °C to 110 °C as the reductive amination of pyruvic acid advanced, peaking at 86 %. Some residual intermediates remained, with no byproducts observed. Upon further elevating temperature from 120 ℃ to 130 ℃, there was a notable increase in intermediate conversion. Nonetheless, the selectivity of alanine declined significantly due to the undesired hydrogenation of pyruvic acid to lactic acid at excessive temperatures. Next, the impact of H2 pressure in the reductive amination of pyruvic acid was investigated. As illustrated in Fig. 3, as the H2 pressure increased, the selectivity of alanine initially rose and peaked at 86 % under 1 MPa. Subsequently, as the pressure continued to rise from 1 to 2 MPa, there was a notable increase in intermediate imine conversion and the selectivity of alanine declined due to the hydrogenation of pyruvic acid into lactic acid. Therefore, the optimum H2 pressure was identified as 1 MPa. Subsequently, the influence of reaction time on this particular reaction was assessed, with the outcomes displayed in Fig. 4. As depicted in the figure, the conversion of pyruvic acid consistently remained at 99 % within the evaluated time frame of 1.5–4 h. The selectivity of alanine gradually improved with increase in reaction time, and reached its maximum of selectivity of 87 % in 3 h. Despite prolonging the reaction time from 2 to 3 h, there was merely a one percent elevation in the selectivity of alanine. Hence, the optimal reaction time was identified as 2 h, resulting in a yield of 86 %. Ultimately, the impact of catalyst amount in this reaction was examined. As depicted in Fig. 5, the conversion of pyruvic acid consistently stood at 99 %, whereas the selectivity of alanine fluctuated in correlation with alterations in the mass ratio of substrate to catalyst. When the mass ratio of substrate to catalyst was 10: 1 or less, the selectivity of alanine remained constant at 99 %. Nonetheless, as the mass ratio surpassed 12.5: 1, the selectivity of alanine progressively diminished due to the deficient conversion of imine intermediary to alanine at lower catalyst quantities. Consequently, the best mass ratio of substrate to catalyst was found to be 10: 1. According to the experimental findings mentioned previously, the most optimum reaction conditions for the reductive amination of pyruvic acid to alanine using 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst were identified. These conditions included temperature 110 ℃, reaction time 2 h, mass ratio of substrate to catalyst 10: 1, H2 pressure 1 MPa, and the application of excess ammonia. With these optimized conditions, the conversion of pyruvic acid achieved 99 %, while maintaining a remarkable alanine selectivity of 99 % and an impressive alanine yield of 99 %. 3.3 Recycle test The potential for reusing 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 in the reductive amination of pyruvic acid was assessed ( Fig. 6). To ensure the accuracy of the findings, a substrate to catalyst mass ratio of 30: 1 was selected to regulate the alanine yield at approximately 46 % in the initial experiment. Following the reaction, the catalyst was easily retrieved utilizing a magnet and subsequently reused following a thorough cleansing with methanol and water. Fig. 6 shows that the catalyst's performance was consistent through 7 recycling cycles, with the alanine yield staying relatively constant. This confirms the long-lasting stability of the catalytic procedure. 3.4 Catalyst characterization Fig. 7a displays the XRD patterns of Ni@SiO2-0.2, Co@SiO2-0.2, 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, and the used 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalysts. In the fresh Ni@SiO2-0.2, prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5, 51.9, and 76.4° attributed to (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Ni0 are observed [23], with no peaks corresponding to NiO, confirming the predominance of Ni0 form in the Ni@SiO2-0.2. Regarding the fresh Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.5°, 75.5°, and 79.5° linked to (100), (101), (110), and (102) crystal planes of Co0 are noted [24], with no peaks corresponding to CoO, affirming the prevalence of Co0 form in Co@SiO2-0.2 catalysts. In the fresh 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 sample, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5, 51.9, and 76.4° attributed to (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Ni0, alongside diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.5°, 75.5°, and 79.5° linked to (100), (101), (110), and (102) crystal planes of Co0 are observed. No peaks corresponding to NiO and CoO are detected, affirming the presence of Ni0 and Co0 forms in 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalysts. In addition, the diffraction peak of crystal plane of Ni@SiO2-0.2 was sharper than that of 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, indicating that the dispersion of active metal was better after introducing Co into the catalyst, reducing the size of the grain, improving its catalytic activity. The catalytic activity of 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 was higher than that of Ni@SiO2-0.2 and Co@SiO2-0.2. Upon introducing Co into the Ni@SiO2-0.2, a negative shift in the diffraction peaks of crystal plane was observed (Fig. 7b), These shifts were observed at 2θ = 44.38°, 51.94°, and 76.28°, indicating the formation of a Ni-Co alloy in 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst [25,26]. These findings also suggest a collaborative impact between Ni and Co, consequently enhancing the performance of the catalyst [27]. In the X-ray diffraction analysis of the used 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst, there is no presence of NiO or CoO peaks, signifying that Ni and Co are consistently present in their metallic state (Ni0 and Co0) throughout the catalytic process. Furthermore, no distinct SiO2 diffraction peaks are observed, suggesting the SiO2 present in the catalyst is amorphous [27]. XPS analysis was conducted to study the surface composition and chemical states of Ni and Co in the Ni@SiO2-0.2, Co@SiO2-0.2, 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, and used 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalysts. Fig. 8a displays the comprehensive XPS spectrum of the xNi-yCo@SiO2-0.2 catalysts, showcasing clear peaks that correspond to elements such as C 1 s, O 1 s, Si 2p, Ni 2p, and Co 2p, providing confirmation of their existence. The XPS analysis indicated that the surface content of Ni and Co is lower compared to the results obtained from ICP and EDS analyses ( Table 2). The disparities indicated that most of the Ni and Co were not positioned on the catalyst's surface, backing the idea of a core-shell configuration for this catalyst [28]. Fig. 8b displays the Co 2p XPS data of the catalysts. In the catalyst of Co@SiO2-0.2, two Co0 2p peaks are evident at 794.41 eV (Co0 2p1/2) and 779.02 eV (Co0 2p3/2) with satellite peaks, respectively, and two peaks representing Co2+ 2p1/2 and Co2+ 2p3/2 [23]. During analysis, the strong reducibility of Co0 inevitably leads to the presence of Co2+, which can be attributed to oxidation. In comparison to Co@SiO2-0.2, the Co0 2p1/2 peak of the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst moves from 794.41 to 793.23 eV, while the Co0 2p3/2 peak moves from 779.02 to 777.78 eV. In addition, compared to Ni@SiO2-0.2, the Ni0 2p1/2 peak of the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst moves from 871.40 to 872.02 eV, and the Ni0 2p3/2 peak moves from 853.16 to 854.49 eV (Fig. 8b and c). These changes suggest that the mutual doping of Ni and Co NPs led to a decrease in the binding energy of Co0 due to the force between Co0 and Ni0, promoting the desorption of alanine on the Co surface, consequently boosting its catalytic activity [24]. Overall, these findings imply the existence of a synergistic effect between Ni and Co, potentially resulting in the formation of a Ni-Co alloy [29]. Comparing the XPS spectrum of the fresh 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst to that of the used catalyst, no particularly significant inherent differences were observed (Fig. 8a). This suggests that the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 sample demonstrated exceptional stability during the catalytic run, as evidenced by the recycling test. Additionally, in the O 2p spectrum (Fig. 8d), compared to Co@SiO2-0.2, the negative shift of the Si-O peak in 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 suggests that the interaction between Co and Ni is accomplished through bridging O, possibly [30,31]. The experiments of H2-TPR were carried out to obtain the reducibility data of NiO and CoO species, assess the interaction between metallic Co and Ni, and examine the interaction between Co-Ni and SiO2. The results of H2-TPR characterization can be seen in Fig. 9. In the NiO@SiO2-0.2 and CoO@SiO2-0.2 samples, a single peak for H2 reduction is observed at temperatures of 351 ℃ and 323 ℃, respectively, indicating the reduction of NiO to Ni and CoO to Co. The 3Ni-7CoO@SiO2-0.2 sample only presents a single peak for H2 reduction is observed at temperatures of 310 ℃ (Fig. 9b). Compared with that of NiO@SiO2-0.2 sample, the reduction peak of 3NiO-7CoO@SiO2-0.2 sample shifted towards lower temperature (from 323 to 310 ℃), suggesting possible interactions between Co and Ni, and further suggesting the possibility of the formation of an alloy between Ni and Co [32,33]. The samples of 5NiO-5CoO@SiO2-0.2, 4NiO-6CoO@SiO2-0.2, and 1NiO-9CoO@SiO2-0.2 exhibit two H2 reduction peaks (Fig. 9a). In comparison to the NiO@SiO2-0.2 catalyst, the peak for reduction shifted towards lower temperature, suggesting the existence of weak interactions between Ni and Co [34], those catalysts activity is relatively low (Table 1, entries 8, 9, and 12) [35,36]. To enhance comprehension of the textural makeup of that samples, N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted. The results in Fig. 10a and Table 3 indicate that as the ratio of Si to Ni-Co increased, both the specific surface areas and pore sizes decreased [37]. Additionally, all samples displayed type IV isotherms with an H1 hysteresis loop (Fig. 10b), suggesting a mesoporous structure characterized by a consistent and organized pore distribution [38]. The specific surface area and pore size of the used sample showed slight changes, compared to the fresh sample, confirming the durability of the catalyst (3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2). In order to improve our comprehension regarding the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-z catalysts and its fundamental morphology, the TEM was utilized. The results reveal a clear core-shell structure in which the core is composed of Ni-Co, and the shell is made of SiO2 ( Fig. 11e). Furthermore, HAADF-STEM imaging (Fig. 11h) shows faint halo surrounding each large bright spot [39]. Among them, the bright spot is the Ni-Co particles, while the faint halo is SiO2. The Ni and Co active species are dispersed and wrapped within the SiO2 shell as NPs with an average size of 20–30 nm, while the SiO2 nanospheres have diameters ranging from 35 to 45 nm (Figure S4) [40]. From the HR-TEM image (Fig. 11f) of the catalyst, it can be observed that the crystal lattice of the catalyst is 0.215 nm, which is consistent with the interplanar spacing of the Ni-Co alloy phase (111) surface, indicating the formation of the Ni-Co alloy phase [41]. The TEM image of Ni-Co NPs is shown in Fig. 11a. Comparing Fig. 11a with Fig. 11b, c, and d reveals that the exposed Ni-Co NPs tend to aggregate more. The SiO2 coating on 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.1, 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.3 can inhibit the aggregation of Ni-Co cores, resulting in a more uniform and stable distribution of the active components [42,43]. An examination of Fig. 11b, c, and d indicates that the increase in SiO2 shell thickness with higher amounts of TEOS, affecting that catalytic performance [44]. It can be seen that after encapsulation, the particle size of the Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst is about 44.07 nm (Figure S4a). Upon the addition of Ni to the Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst, there was a slight reduction in particle size, resulting in an average particle size of around 39.30 nm (Figure S4b) [45,46]. It has improved the crystallinity of the catalyst, which may weaken the interaction between the metal and carrier, promoting the dispersion of the metal particles [47]. The elemental mapping experiment was performed on the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2–0.2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 11i and S4. The image reveals the presence of Ni, Co, O, and Si elements, which are uniformly distributed, demonstrating almost no metal aggregation phenomenon. Scheme 1 demonstrates that the condensation reaction of carbonyl and ammonia serves as a key step in the reductive amination process of pyruvic acid to alanine. The presence of the appropriate number of acidic sites and optimal acidity plays a crucial role in promoting the adsorption of imine intermediates, ammonia, and substrates, thus boosting the catalytic process of aminating carbonyl compounds. However, an excess of acidity impedes the condensation between ammonia and carbonyl, as well as hinder the products and ammonia desorption. The determination of catalyst surface acidities was carried out using the NH3-TPD method [48,49]. Analysis of the NH3-TPD for the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-z samples in Fig. 13 reveals two distinct NH3 desorption peaks occurring in the temperature range of 50 °C to 700 °C, corresponding to NH3 adsorption on strong and weak acid sites present on the surfaces of the catalysts. It shows a clear relationship between the ratio of Si to Ni-Co and the desorption temperature of ammonia at acid sites. Evaluation of the NH3 adsorption capacity assessment for each catalyst are detailed in Table 4. Among all tested catalysts, the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst exhibited the most suitable acidity strength and an optimal number of acidic sites, with an NH3 adsorption capacity of 0.5552 mmol/g. This enhances the adsorption of NH3 and the intermediate imine, as well as the desorption of alanine, resulting in the highest catalytic performance. In contrast, the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2–0.1 catalyst, with an NH3 adsorption capacity of 0.3659 mmol/g, demonstrates weaker acidity strength and fewer acidic sites, which hinders imine adsorption and leads to slightly poorer catalytic performance. Additionally, the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.3 catalyst, with an NH3 adsorption capacity of 0.7937 mmol/g, shows excessive acidity strength and an overabundance of acidic sites, resulting in most active sites being occupied by NH3 molecules and obstructing alanine desorption, thus exhibiting inferior catalytic activity [50]. 3.5 First-principles calculations Next, theoretical calculations will be employed to explain the high catalytic activity of specific ratios of Ni and Co in 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out with the VASP code [51]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [52] was used to process the exchange–correlation, while the projectoraugmented-wave pseudopotential (PAW) [53] was applied with a kinetic energy cut-off of 500 eV, which was utilized to describe the expansion of the electronic eigenfunctions. The vacuum thickness was set to be 15 Å to minimize interlayer interactions. The Brillouin-zone integration was sampled by a Γ-centered 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point. All atomic positions were fully relaxed until energy and force reached a tolerance of 1 × 10−5 eV and 0.03 eV/Å, respectively. The dispersion corrected DFT-D method was employed to consider the long-range interactions [54]. We selected the βc-SiO2 (111) surface as the catalyst support and investigated the catalytic performance of Ni, Co, and their alloys loaded on the surface for the amination of acetone. According to XRD characterization analysis, we selected the crystal face of Ni (111), Co (111), and Ni (111)-Co (111) in Ni@SiO2-0.2, Co@SiO2-0.2, and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, respectively. The configurations of Ni and Co loaded on SiO2 are shown in Fig. 13d-f. The advantage of SiO2 as a catalyst support lies in its high surface area and porous structure. The well-developed porosity and permeability of SiO2 facilitate the transportation of reactants and products, thereby increasing the contact area between reaction intermediates and active metal sites, enhancing reaction efficiency, and improving the catalyst utilization. Moreover, SiO2, as a stable inorganic material, provides protection for the Ni-Co alloy catalyst against oxidation or other adverse environmental conditions, thus prolonging the catalyst's lifespan and stability. In terms of tuning the reaction activity and selectivity, SiO2 exhibits a certain degree of acidity, which enables the regulation of the acid-base environment in the amination reaction of acetone. This acidity helps to control the reaction rate, product selectivity, and suppress undesired side reactions, thereby enhancing the selectivity and purity of the target products. The d-band centers of three surface configurations were investigated, as shown in Figure 14. The calculated d-band centers for Co and Ni surfaces (Figures 14a and b) were found to be −1.428 and −1.603 eV, respectively. The d-band center for the Ni-Co surface was calculated to be −1.818 eV (Figure 14c), indicating that the formation of the Ni-Co alloy shifted the d-band center away from the Fermi level. The proximity of the d-band of the catalyst to the Fermi level correlates with stronger adsorption of reaction intermediates. For the amination catalytic reaction of acetone, it is crucial that the adsorption of the substrate on the metal catalyst surface is not too strong, as excessively strong adsorption can hinder the desorption of the reaction products and lead to catalyst deactivation. Conversely, adsorption should not be too weak either, as weak adsorption may result in insufficient activation of the adsorbate and low reaction efficiency. Regarding NH3, it is highly prone to adsorption on the metal surface, and it can even hinder the adsorption of hydrogen atoms on the metal surface. Therefore, the reaction needs to be conducted in an environment where adsorption is relatively weak. The relatively low adsorption energies observed on the surface suggest that NH3 exhibits the weakest interaction with the Ni-Co alloy, which may be advantageous for our reaction. To further investigate the mechanism of the reaction, we constructed adsorption configurations of the reaction intermediates on the surfaces of the three catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 15. Initially, the acetone molecules were adsorbed on the catalyst surface, interacting with the catalyst. Subsequently, ammonia molecules were also adsorbed on the catalyst surface, forming an amination intermediate with acetone. During the amination process, the carbon-oxygen (C-O) bond of acetone underwent cleavage, while simultaneously forming a carbon-nitrogen (C=NH) bond with the nitrogen atom from ammonia. Furthermore, the hydrogen atoms adsorbed on the catalyst surface reacted with the amination intermediate, leading to the hydrogenation of the aminated product of acetone. This process involves key steps such as molecular adsorption, bond cleavage and formation, as well as hydrogen addition [54]. Through the participation of the catalyst, the amination of acetone is successfully transformed into a product with amino functionality. The comprehensive understanding of these molecular transformations sheds light on the important role played by the catalyst, as it facilitates the adsorption, bond-breaking, and formation processes, as well as the addition of hydrogen. This catalytic process enables the conversion of acetone into a product with amino groups, offering promising prospects for the synthesis of functionalized compounds [55,56]. Besides, the reaction free energy profiles and transition states of the amination reaction of acetone on Co@SiO2-0.2, Ni@SiO2-0.2, and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 surfaces were investigated. The cleavage of the C-O bond of acetone and its reaction with NH3 to form CH3CNHCOOH were identified as the potential determining step (PDS) of the entire reaction. The PDS values on Co@SiO2-0.2, Ni@SiO2-0.2, and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 surfaces were determined to be 0.52, 0.41, and 0.32 eV, respectively. The lowest PDS value on the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 surface suggests its thermodynamic favorability for the reaction. Furthermore, this step was also identified as the rate-determining step (RDS) of the overall reaction. The reaction barriers on Co@SiO2-0.2, Ni@SiO2-0.2, and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 surfaces were found to be 1.08, 0.95, and 0.74 eV, respectively. This indicates that the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 surface exhibits the most favorable reaction rate among the studied catalysts. Additionally, Fig. 16 shows, there is a dense charge density accumulation around the pyruvic acid and NH3 coadsorbed species, indicating that electrons are transferred from the substrate to the coadsorbed pyruvic acid, NH3 and H2, and the transferred electrons are 0.69, 0.58, and 0.87 e- for Ni@SiO2-0.2, Co@SiO2-0.2, and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, respectively, according to the Bader charge analysis. In addition, there are notable overlaps between d-orbitals of the metal and valence orbitals of the adsorbates (pyruvic acid and NH3), as shown in the projected density of state (PDOS) in Fig. 16, revealing strong bonding interaction between the coadsorbed gases and 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2. Accordingly, the metal atoms anchored on SiO2 indeed promote the initial activation of pyruvic acid and NH3 and trigger the next hydrogenation reaction [57]. The differential charge density maps of acetone adsorbed on the catalyst surfaces revealed the favorable activation capability of the Ni-Co alloy for the reaction. These findings provide valuable insights into the energetics and kinetics of the amination reaction of acetone on different catalyst surfaces. The results highlight the thermodynamic and kinetic advantages of the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 surface and emphasize the promising activation functionality of the Ni-Co alloy for the reaction. Differential charge density maps (Fig. 16d, e, and f) reveal that in the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2, Ni and Co form an alloy, resulting in a decreased electron density around the Ni-Co atoms and an increase in the electron density of the CO group in the adjacent pyruvic acid. Furthermore, the electron density in the bonding region is more concentrated, leading to a more stable adsorption. This enhances the adsorption capability of pyruvic acid. The superior activation ability of the Ni-Co active sites for pyruvic acid molecules arises from charge localization and the weakened bonding strength of CO, making it easier for the dangling O atoms to break bonds and participate in subsequent reactions. Moreover, An intriguing observation was made. It was found that the lower the adsorption energy of ammonia on the metal surface, and the smaller the difference in adsorption energies between ammonia and hydrogen atoms on the metal surface, the higher the catalytic activity of the metal catalyst for the hydroxylamine reduction reaction. In our computational results, the order of decreasing adsorption energy differences was Co@SiO2-0.2 (0.37 eV) > Ni@SiO2 (0.25 eV) > 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 (0.22 eV), while the order of increasing reactivity was Co@SiO2-0.2 < Ni@SiO2-0.2 < 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2. This implies that a smaller difference in adsorption energy between ammonia and hydrogen atoms on the metal surface corresponds to higher catalytic activity for the ketones reductive amination reaction under the influence of the respective metal catalyst. This finding suggests that by developing Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts, the adsorption strength of the metal components on ammonia molecules has been reduced, leading to further enhancement of the catalytic performance in the acetone amination reaction. Finally, the study looked into the adsorption process of pyruvic acid and imine within the pores of SiO2. The orientation of pyruvic acid and imine on βc-SiO2 is perpendicular to the surface. A hydrogen bond forms between the O atoms of pyruvic acid and the H atoms of βc-SiO2, as well as between the N atoms of imine and the H atoms of βc-SiO2. The adsorption behavior on βc-SiO2 primarily relies on the creation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds. During adsorption, pyruvic acid or imine molecules form hydrogen bonds with two hydroxyl groups in silanol. One group receives a proton from pyruvic acid or imine, while the other group provides a proton to them. The adsorption structure is depicted in Fig. 17, where the SiO2 shell exhibits a cage structure with ring-like pores. The vary pore sizes of SiO2, with narrow pores at 3.41 nm (Si: Ni = 0.3), mid-sized pores at 4.88 nm (Si: Ni = 0.2), and large pores at 6.58 nm (Si: Ni = 0.1). Smaller pores impede the diffusion of pyruvic acid and imine towards metal sites, while wider pores facilitate their direct diffusion to these sites. According to Table 5, the adsorption mechanisms include physical adsorption, and the adsorption procedures are exothermic. As the size of the SiO2 pore increases, the capacity for pyruvic acid adsorption decreases steadily, leading to some pyruvic acid diffusing towards the active metal site, where it undergoes a hydrogenation reaction to yield lactic acid, as confirmed by experimental results. Conversely, as the SiO2 pore size decreases, the capacity for imine adsorption gradually rises, inhibiting the spread of imine to the Ni and Co and ultimately diminishing the production of alanine. This supports the notion that catalysts with the correct pore size (3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2) exhibit enhanced catalytic performance and increased selectivity (99 % yield). 4 Conclusion A 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 catalyst with a core-shell structure was designed for the reductive amination of pyruvic acid to alanine. This catalyst exhibited exceptional performance in the reaction, achieving a 99 % alanine yield. Furthermore, it displayed remarkable stability, allowing for 7 cycles of recycling without significant activity loss. The outstanding catalytic activity of the 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 could be attributed to the isolating impact of SiO2 shell which allows the reactants to diffuse to the active Co and Ni sites while inhibiting direct hydrogenation side reactions. Combining first-principles and experimental data, by inter-doping Ni and Co, Ni-Co alloy is formed, the electronic structure and properties of the metal were adjusted, and the d-band center of Ni-Co is significantly reduced, which is conducive to the desorption of products. In addition, the reaction energy barrier is significantly reduced. Furthermore, it is proposed that catalysts exhibit better reductive amination reaction performance when there is a smaller difference in adsorption energy between NH3 and H2 atoms on the metal surface. coredata.dc:description: A core-shell structured catalyst 3Ni-7Co@SiO2-0.2 was created to facilitate the reductive amination of pyruvic acid into alanine and the yield of alanine is up to 99 %. The SiO2 shell played a crucial role in spatial isolation effect, preventing the direct hydrogenation of pyruvic acid and improving the selectivity of alanine. By inter-doping Ni and Co, the electronic structure and properties are adjusted, the d-band center is reduced which is beneficial to the desorption of the product and the reaction barrier is reduced. Furthermore, it is proposed that catalysts exhibit better reductive amination reaction performance when there is a smaller difference in adsorption energy between NH3 and H2 atoms on the metal surface.

coredata.dc:title: Modulating the electronic structure of Ni and Co in core-shell structured catalysts to enhance the efficiency of reductive amination of pyruvic acid
